awd_titl_txt: Conference: Group Theory and Number Theory: Interactions
awd_abstract_narration:
This grant is to support travel of participants to attend the conference "Group Theory and Number Theory: Interactions", which will take place October 16-20, 2023 at Princeton University. Bringing together experts in the areas group theory and number theory, this conference will provide new networking opportunities and stimulate important research collaborations between researchers in these two branches of mathematics. Group theory is motivated by the study of symmetries of objects found in many areas of science, art, and technology, from molecular structures, to the spin of particles, to the patterns in cryptosystems, to the structure of musical chords. Number theory is motivated by the study of the integers, prime numbers, integer-valued functions, and generalizations of these objects, and has applications to the same areas as group theory. In many of the key problems in group theory, one sees natural relationships to number theory, and vice versa. Recent advances and open conjectures in the two areas have made it clear that there is a strong benefit to being able to combine the techniques from both. This conference will inspire progress on important questions, while also broadening the tools and ideas available to researchers in both areas, and fostering a new generation of researchers studying interactions of group theory and number theory. Students, early-career researchers, and mathematicians who identify as women and other underrepresented groups will be especially encouraged to participate. 

One of the most well-known examples with a clear relationship between group theory (and, more specifically, representation theory) and number theory is the Langlands program.  The main speakers, representing some of the most influential names and trends currently in the two areas of group theory and number theory, will give talks discussing new results related to the Langlands program, as well as new results on algebraic groups, permutation groups, probabilistic approaches to representation theory and word growth, local-global conjectures in character theory, and other topics that bridge the two areas of group theory/representation theory and number theory. The conference website is: https://sites.google.com/view/tiep60conference/

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This conference grant supported travel of main invited participants, as well as other participants who were graduate students, junior researchers, or from groups traditionally under-represented in the mathematical sciences, to attend the conference “Group Theory and Number Theory: Interactions”. The conference was held at Princeton University, October 16-20, 2023, and was organized by the PI, along with Robert Guralnick (University of Southern California), Nick Katz (Princeton University), and Gabriel Navarro (University of Valencia, Spain). The 18 main speakers represented some of the biggest names and trends currently in the two areas of group theory and number theory. The solutions of multiple long-standing, influential conjectures were announced at the meeting.

With this conference, we bridged the gap between the two areas of group theory and number theory, and encouraged collaboration between leading experts and junior researchers alike from the two fields. In this way, we hope we have helped to broaden the tools and ideas available to researchers in both areas and fostered a new generation of interdisciplinary researchers studying interactions of group theory and number theory.

Graduate students and postdocs who otherwise would not have been able to attend were prioritized for funding through the grant. These junior researchers had the opportunity to build their networks and discuss their work with both peers and some of the most prominant mathematicians in the area. One such student wrote "...the conference successfully triggered my curiosity about so many wonderful things people have done in this field, and it has been a strong motivation to me to keep continuing."
